tha21:1218: "Now that I’ve gone forthFrom the home life into homelessness,I’m assailedBy the reckless thoughts of the Dark One.
tha21:1219: Even if a thousand mighty princes and great archersWell trained, with strong bows,Might completely surround me,I would not flee.
tha21:1220: And if women come,Many more than that,They won’t scare me:I stand firm in Dhamma.
tha21:1221: Only once did I personally hearFrom the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,About the path leading tonibbāna;My mind was delighted with that teaching.
tha21:1222: Wicked one, if you come near meAs I live like this,I’ll act in such a way that you, Death,Will not even see the path I travel.
tha21:1223: Entirely abandoning likes and dislikes,Along with thoughts attached to the household life,He wouldn’t get entangled in anything,He is a monk without entanglements.
tha21:1224: On this earth and in the sky,Whatever form you take when entering the worldWears out, it is all impermanent;Reflective people live understanding this.
tha21:1225: People are bound in their attachmentsTo what is seen, heard, and thought.Being imperturbable, expel desire for these things;For one they call a sage does not cling to these things.
tha21:1226: Attached to sixty kinds of wrong views with their modes of thought,Unenlightened people are fixed in wrong principles;But that monk wouldn’t go to any sectarian group,Still less would he take up corrupt ways.
tha21:1227: Clever, and for a long time established insamādhi,Free of deceit, disciplined, without envy,The sage has realised the state of peace,Since he has realizednibbāna, he awaits his time.
tha21:1228: Abandon conceit, Gotama!Completely abandon the path to conceit;Infatuated with the path to conceit,You’ve had regrets for a long time.
tha21:1229: Smeared by smears and slain by conceit,People fall into hell.When people slain by conceit are reborn in hell,They grieve for a long time.
tha21:1230: But a monk never grievesIf they practice rightly, a victor of the path.They have renown and happiness,And they rightly call him a ‘Seer of Dhamma’.
tha21:1231: So don’t be hard-hearted, be energetic,With hindrances abandoned, purified,And with conceit abandoned completely,Be at peace, and use knowledge to make an end."
tha21:1232: "I’ve got a burning desire for pleasure;My mind is on fire!Please, out of compassion, Gotama,Tell me how to quench the flames."
tha21:1233: "Your mind is on fireBecause of a perversion of perception.Avoid noticing the attractive aspect of thingsThat provokes lust.
tha21:1234: Meditate on the unattractive,Unified, insamādhi;With mindfulness immersed in the body,Make much of disenchantment.
tha21:1235: Meditate on the signless,Throw out the underlying tendency to conceit,And when you have a breakthrough in understanding conceit,You will live at peace."
tha21:1236: "Speak only such wordsAs do not hurt yourselfNor harm others.Such speech is truly well spoken.
tha21:1237: Speak only pleasing words,Words received gladly;Pleasing words are thoseThat don’t have bad effects on others.
tha21:1238: Truth itself is the undying word:This is an eternal principle.Realists say that the Dhamma and its meaningAre grounded in the truth.
tha21:1239: The reliable words spoken by the BuddhaFor realizingnibbāna,And making an end of suffering:This really is the best kind of speech."
tha21:1240: "His understanding is profound, he is wise,He is skilled in knowing the path and what is not the path;Sāriputta, of great understanding,Teaches Dhamma to the monks.
tha21:1241: He teaches in brief,Or he speaks at length,His voice, which sounds like a myna bird,Inspires intuition.
tha21:1242: While he teachesThe monks hear his sweet voice,Sounding attractive,Clear and mellifluous;They listen joyfullyWith hearts uplifted."
tha21:1243: "Today, on the fifteenth dayuposatha,500 monks have gathered together to purify their precepts.Tshese sages without affliction have cut off their fetters and bonds,They will not be reborn again into any state of existence.
tha21:1244: Just as a wheel-rolling emperorSurrounded by ministersTravels all around thisLand that is circled by sea;
tha21:1245: So disciples with the three knowledges,Destroyers of death,Attend upon the winner of the battle,The unsurpassed caravan leader.
tha21:1246: All are sons of the Blessed One —There is no rubbish here.I bow to the Kinsman of the Sun,The destroyer of the dart of craving.
tha21:1247: Over a thousand monksAttend on the Fortunate OneAs he teaches the immaculate Dhamma:Nibbāna, free of fear from any direction.
tha21:1248: They hear the stainless DhammaTaught by the Buddha.The Buddha is so brilliant,Revered by the monastic Saṅgha.
tha21:1249: Blessed One, you are called ‘elephant’,Supreme among all sages.You are like a great cloudThat rains on your disciples.
tha21:1250: Setting out from his daytime dwellingWanting to see the teacher;Great hero, your disciple,Vangisa bows at your feet."
tha21:1251: "Overcoming Māra’s devious path,I wander with hard-heartedness dissolved.See him, the liberator from bonds,Unattached, teaching the Dhamma by analysing each section.
tha21:1252: He has explained in many waysThe path to cross the flood.Since the deathless has been explained,The seers of Dhamma stand unshakable.
tha21:1253: Like a piercing light,He’s seen the transcendence of all states of rebirth;Knowing it and witnessing it,He taught it first to the group of five.
tha21:1254: When Dhamma is well taught like this,How could those that understand Dhamma be heedless?Therefore you should train in the teaching of the Blessed One,Heedful, and always reverent."
tha21:1255: "The senior monk who was awakened after the BuddhaKoṇḍañña is keenly energetic,And regularly gains the meditative statesOf happiness and seclusion.
tha21:1256: Whatever can be realisedBy a disciple following the teacher,He has attained it all,Diligent in training himself.
tha21:1257: With great power and the three knowledges,Skilled in reading the minds of others,Koṇḍañña, the heir to the Buddha,Bows at the teacher’s feet."
tha21:1258: "As the sage, who has gone beyond suffering,Sits on the mountainside,He is attended by disciples with the three knowledges,Destroyers of death.
tha21:1259: Moggallāna, of great psychic power,Searches with his mind,Looking into their mindsFor one liberated without attachments.
tha21:1260: So they attend upon Gotama,The sage gone beyond suffering,Who is endowed with all attributes,And with a multitude of qualities."
tha21:1261: "Just as, when the clouds have vanished,The moon shines in the sky, stainless as the sun,So Angīrasa, great sage,Your renown outshines the entire world."
tha21:1262: "We used to wander, drunk on poetry,From village to village, from town to town;Then we saw the Buddha,Who has gone beyond all Dhammas.
tha21:1263: He, the sage gone beyond suffering,Taught me the Dhamma;When we heard the Dhamma, we became confident —Faith arose in us.
tha21:1264: Hearing him speak ofThe aggregates, the sense-bases,And the elements, I understood.I went forth into homelessness.
tha21:1265: Truly, Tathāgatas ariseFor the benefit of the manyMen and womenWho follow their teachings.
tha21:1266: Truly, it is for their benefitThat the sage indeed realised awakening;The monks and nuns, who seeThe natural principles of the Dhamma.
tha21:1267: The seer, the Buddha,The Kinsman of the Sun,Has well taught the four noble truthsOut of compassion for living beings.
tha21:1268: Suffering, the origin of suffering,The transcending of suffering ,And the noble eight-fold pathThat leads to the stilling of suffering.
tha21:1269: As these things were spoken,So I have seen them.I’ve realized my own true goal,The Buddha’s instruction is completed.
tha21:1270: It was so welcome for me,As I was in the presence of the Buddha.Of things which are shared,I encountered the best.
tha21:1271: I’ve realised the perfection of direct knowledge;I have supernormal hearing;I have the three knowledges and psychic powers,I’m skilled at reading the minds of others."
tha21:1272: "I ask the teacher unrivalled in understanding,Who has cut off all doubts in this very life —Has a monk died at Aggāḷava, who wasWell-known, famous, and attained tonibbāna?
tha21:1273: Nigrodhakappa was his name;It was given to that brahman by you, Blessed One.Yearning for freedom, energetic, firmly seeing the Dhamma,He wandered in your honor.
tha21:1274: O Sakyan, who sees all around,All of us wish to know about that disciple.Our ears are eager to hear,For you’re truly the most excellent teacher.
tha21:1275: Cut off our doubt, declare this to us;Your understanding is vast, tell us of hisnibbāna!You see all around, so speak among us,Like the thousand-eyed Sakka in the assembly of the gods!
tha21:1276: Whatever ties there are, or paths to delusion,Or things that are on the side of unknowing,Or that are bases of doubt:When it comes to the Tathāgata there are none;Among people, his eye is the best.
tha21:1277: For if no man were ever to disperse defilements,Like the wind dispersing a mass of clouds,Darkness would cover the whole world,And even a lamp would not shine.
tha21:1278: The wise are makers of light;My hero, that is what I think of you.We’ve come to you for your insight and knowledge:Here in this assembly, declare to us about Kappāyana.
tha21:1279: Swiftly send forth your sweet voice,Like a goose stretching its neck, gently honking,The sound is smooth, with a lovely tone:Alert, we are all listening to you.
tha21:1280: You have entirely abandoned birth and death;Restrained and pure, speak the Dhamma!Unenlightened people can’t fulfil all their wishes,But Tathāgatas can achieve what they intend.
tha21:1281: Your answer is definitive, and we will accept it,For you have perfect understanding.We raise our hands inañjalīone last time,Your understanding is unrivalled,So do not knowingly confuse us.
tha21:1282: Knowing the noble Dhamma from top to bottom,Your energy is unrivalled, so do not knowingly confuse us.Like a man in the baking summer sun would long for water,I long for the rain of your voice to fall on my ears.
tha21:1283: Surely KappāyanaDid not live the spiritual life in vain?Did he realisenibbāna,Or did he still have a remnant of defilement?Let us hear what kind of liberation he had!"
tha21:1284: "He cut off craving for conception and corporeality in this very life,The river of darkness that had long lain within him.He has entirely crossed over birth and death."So declared the Blessed One, the leader of the five.
tha21:1285: "Now that I have heard your words,Best of sages, I am confident.My question, it seems, was not in vain,The brahman did not deceive me.
tha21:1286: As he spoke, so he acted;He was a disciple of the Buddha.He cut the net of death the illusionist,So extended and strong.
tha21:1287: Blessed One, Kappāyana sawThe starting point of grasping.He has gone beyond the realm of death,So very hard to cross.
tha21:1288: God of gods, best of men, I bow to you;And to your son,Who follows your example, a great heroAn elephant, true son of an elephant."
